author: t2dfight
body:
Ozempic helps most people lose weight if you put in the work to change your diet and exercise. 

I'm down 72 lbs from diagnosis and starting ozempic.

author: [deleted]

author: t2dfight
body: I have a cgm as well. My last a1c was 4.9 so I don't check as much as when I first was diagnosed. Everything is pointing towards potential remission for so long as I keep my diet and exercise right.

author: t2dfight

author: [deleted]
body: I haven’t thought about bariatric surgery. Is that like a permanent Ozempic kind of thing?

author: t2dfight
body:
It's permanent no matter the type, can be expensive, and there can be side effects and complications but according to most studies, it's incredibly effective for type 2 especially if you've ran out of options. If I can't keep my weight off, honestly, I'm exploring it as a future option. One of my friends had it and she's doing great. 

https://www.nih.gov/news-events/nih-research-matters/weight-loss-surgery-yields-long-term-benefits-type-2-diabetes

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5553790/

author: rubberduckie819
body: My A1c is down from 6.9 to 6.2 and I've lost a little over 20 lbs in 10 weeks.

author: [deleted]
body: That’s awesome

author: rubberduckie819
body:
It really is an amazing tool. I'm still on the 0.5mg dose and the plan is to stay there. I haven't had any really bad side effects either. Just some mild nausea. 

It's really helped the noise in my brain around food. I crave sweets less and I actually feel full when I've eaten a reasonable amount of food instead of only feeling full after giant portions. It's kind of amazing.

author: Adventurous_Row928
body: I’m starting my 4th month on Ozempic. My a1c is down to 6.5 from 8.3 and I’ve lost 20 pounds. I would like to lose 50 more, but will be thrilled if it’s only another 30.

author: Rude-Tea9577
body: I’m on mounjaro so similar and it has been a complete game changer for me. I did keto for a long time and got my A1c to 5.9 and lost 30lbs. I just couldn’t do it anymore. I’m from an Okinawan family and we love a lot of dishes that I had to cut things out of. My doctor suggested mounjaro. I started last September and have lost 64 additional pounds, dropped one of my blood pressure meds, lowered my heart rate and dropped my a1c to 4.9 and i think it has even help with my ocd. The only down side I have had so far is the constipation.

author: SmarcusStroman
body: I love hearing the Ozempic success stories from people but I’ve been on it a few years now and it fucks me right up. I had to go down to an eighth of my recommended dose just to not vomit constantly. Finally starting to ramp back up again and hoping the results follow!

author: ComprehensiveMall165

author: Sugar-ibarleyknowher

I did mounjaro… it was a miracle. I exceeded all my health and weight-loss goals. Then I got so healthy I ran a 5k! 

It’s worth doing. My insurance does cover it and it really allowed me to completely change my lifestyle and diet.

author: EvLokadottr
body:
Combined with eating low carb, I lost 78 pounds on Ozempic. Then gained 15 back. 

But my A1C is holding steady at 5.4, so that's fantastic.

author: WorldFoods
body: Did you stop taking it?

author: EvLokadottr
body: Absolutely not! I taken it every week like clockwork. I never want to go back to the awful ess of uncontrolled diabetes, and for me, diet and exercise alone don't control it.

author: WorldFoods
body: I was just curious since you said you had gained some back. Some people only take it for 3 months bc that’s all their insurance will cover. I can’t decide whether to start it or not but I am legitimately hungry all the time that not having food noises or being hungry sounds amazing.

author: EvLokadottr
body:
Huh. For actual diabetes, or weight loss? Because it's meant for diabetes, which doesn't go away ever. 

I gained some back because the metabolism WILL adjust and fight back, eventually, and my metabolism very much does not want me to not be fat, heh. 

But I take it for my diabetes, to stay alive and nonsuffer serious damage due to high blood glucose. I'm glad that Medicare/Medicaid is sensible about this. 

It is insane to only treat someone's diabetes for 3 months and then just .. stop. It's a lifelong illness that can be controlled but never cured.

author: WorldFoods
body: Maybe the people I have seen talking about it were talking about for weight loss. But I was trying to do research into what my insurance covers and it was specifically for diabetes and it looked like it only covered it for 3 months. But maybe I need to look at it again. I was just diagnosed with diabetes last week so I am still overwhelmed with all the information.

author: EvLokadottr
body:
Talk to your doctor about it. Hopefully they can help. Don't be afraid to ask to see a specialist, either- a lot of general care doctors don't know much about diabetes, or are not up to date on it. 

People taking Ozempic just for weight loss is why there have been persistent Ozempic shortages. They shouldn't be doing that at all. Doctors shouldn't be prescribing it for weight loss at all until the company can truly keep up with demand. It's simple triage. The damage done to diabetics without their meds is a lot faster and harder than putting off weight loss.

author: beeboopdoop
body: I have not personally had Ozempic, but as someone who has been on both Trulicity and Mounjaro, I can say with 100% certainty that you will lose a lot of weight really fast. What no one tells you is that it's expensive, so hopefully your insurance covers it; and if you don't keep using it you will gain back all of the weight that you lost unless you completely change your diet and exercise. I will also mention that Mounjaro had much more of an appetite suppression effect on me than Trulicity...like significantly more.

author: Inevitable_Sun_6907
body: Im on Mounjaro and lost 90 lbs since October 2023 and my last A1C was 5.1 (down from 10.2 in October). It is possible to outeat these glp1 medicines. They give you the opportunity to make real lifestyle changes. They also are a miracle for your glucose control.

author: DollPartsRN
body:
For me, Ozempic use resulted in weight loss, lower A1c (a lot lower!), cholesterol went down, off BP meds, less physical pain, reduction of fatty liver to normal findings in blood work, no more sleep apnea, my thyroid had slowly been creeping up but is now in a really great area per blood tests,  increase in ability to participate and enjoy my life. Secondary to this, my outlook has improved in that I don't have depressive concerns, but that could also be due to hormones and being married to an amazing man, now. 

YMMV, but, I really hope you find great success.

author: roastedbeats333
body: I started Ozempic in January with an A1C of 7.1, by February it was 6.5 with no significant weight loss. By June, my A1C was down to 5.9. My sugars are pretty stable (except when I don’t eat enough, I actually had to lower my dose so I could eat properly). I’ve lost about 55 pounds now. My triglycerides are 121 from 161 (they’ve been elevated for years and this is the first time they’ve been normal since my T2 diagnosis 9 years ago). I do have significant GI issues, but compared to issues from diabetes, I’d gladly take this. My next labs are due in October and I’m hoping for an even lower A1C.

author: roastedbeats333
body: I just recently upped to 2mg. I stayed at 1 for a long time…8 months or so? I hit a plateau with weight loss after 70 pounds so my doctor increased me and it’s been fine. I did go up very slowly though. I still get some nausea but I was taking metformin as well and now I only take Ozempic. My sugars are really good (usually around 100 fasting but I get an occasional spike if I don’t get enough protein). I didn’t go straight from 1 to 2, I did 1.5mg for a month or 2 and that really helped with side effects.

author: SEODRohan

author: wilcojunkie
body: I tried Ozempic but had pretty bad digestive side effects. My endo suggested Mounjaro. I've been on it for a year and a half now. I was struggling with getting my A1C down - it was stubbornly at around 9 to 10 with nighttime highs while I was sleeping. After starting Mounjaro I haven't lost much weight but my A1C has consistently been in the mid 6s since. No real side effects. No more nighttime highs. It's a miracle drug for me.

author: Revolutionary_Oil696
body: As an RN + 25 yrs clinical experience with +8yr of clinical research experience (maternal health, no cardiovascular) ..appreciate and fascinated by the evidence you have brought to our awareness. For so long, the accepted narrative was to prescribe statin drugs to mitigate CV risk in those w/hypercholesterolemia which always struck me as wrong & probably harmful thinking  …there has to be much deeper risk/benefit analysis to consider but had neither time, experience or expert contacts to investigate further outside of maternal health. Although, things are changing in maternal health research now towards a more long term outcomes of how we manage co-morbidities such as hypertension & diabetes during pregnancy (7-10 yr outcomes) vs previous research that focused only on maternal/neonatal delivery & immediate post-partum outcomes. I had been aware from research world from many yrs back they had started looking at inflammatory markers for CV risk assessment & begining to see ads to recruit for these type studies again. All very interesting!

author: IntheHotofTexas
body:
It helps, largely by suppressing appetite. The urge to snack is greatly reduced. And remember that it often is started as carbohydrates are being greatly restricted, and that help a lot with weight loss. So, it really is pretty natural in the ways it works for weight. And weight is worthy taking an effective path to loss, because it is a huge factor in blood glucose. We only recently discovered the mechanism through which obesity increased blood glucose. Weight loss is often the most striking and encouraging source of blood glucose numbers for new diabetics. And you need some early successes, because it won't always be that easy, and I think progress tends to slow as the numbers come down.

All of that reduction in blood glucose will also help with cholesterol. Excess blood glucose damages blood vessel wall, and the body, being pretty good at this sort of thing, produces more cholesterol to repair that damage. There was a time lag, but within a few months of getting decent control of my blood glucose, by cholesterol numbers dropped significantly. Sugar is poison, and everything we to helps. 

I so now take Monjaro, which adds a combines a second similar action. Both work. 

(You can do some research, but all I have learned, particularly recent studies, confirms my that cholesterol is a sign of sugar damage and my refusal to use statins to suppress exactly the body process meant to do repairs.)

author: [deleted]
body: May I ask why you refuse statins? I have high triglycerides and they started me on that med as well as a fibrate medicine

author: IntheHotofTexas
body:
First, is my conclusion on account of many things that cholesterol is a proper produce of the body, one whose function is to repair damage to blood vessels from both sugar and high blood pressure, which can also be on account  of high blood glucose. My own experience is purely anecdotal and so would not be accepted as scientific argument, but it vividly supports that view. 

If that is correct, of course cholesterol is associated with heart disease. It follows the damage, attempting to make repairs, but it's a response, not a cause. 

I will let some fairly recent studies speak to the issue. They involve both the relationship of cholesterol levels to all-cause mortality but also analysis of the statistical fraud that largely created the prevailing medical dogma. The misuse of statistics has long been pointed out. Medical journals are just now becoming willing to point out the error in an overwhelmingly common medical practice. This matters, because statins are not harmless. Neither are many medications, but there should be some significant benefit to go with the potential harm.

**How statistical deception created the appearance that statins are safe and effective in primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease**

We have provided a critical assessment of research on the reduction of cholesterol levels by statin treatment to reduce cardiovascular disease. Our opinion is that although statins are effective at reducing cholesterol levels, they have failed to substantially improve cardiovascular outcomes. We have described the deceptive approach statin advocates have deployed to create the appearance that cholesterol reduction results in an impressive reduction in cardiovascular disease outcomes through their use of a statistical tool called relative risk reduction (RRR), a method which amplifies the trivial beneficial effects of statins. We have also described how the directors of the clinical trials have succeeded in minimizing the significance of the numerous adverse effects of statin treatment. [https://www.researchgate.net/publication/272189007](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/272189007)

**Outcomes of Patients with Normal LDL-Cholesterol at Admission for Acute Coronary Syndromes: Lower Is Not Always Better (2024)** "Moreover, patients with normal LDL-C at admission had an even higher proportion of cardiovascular death in comparison to the high LDL-C group."“What we also consider a novel finding in our study is a greater proportion of patients with psychological disorders requiring medical attention in the low LDL-C group.”  
[https://www.mdpi.com/2308-3425/11/4/120](https://www.mdpi.com/2308-3425/11/4/120)

**Low density lipoprotein cholesterol and all-cause mortality rate: findings from a study on Japanese community-dwelling persons (2021)**  
"The current results, based on a follow-up study of people aged 22 years and older, show that having very low LDL-C levels (< 70 mg/dL) is predictive of higher all-cause mortality, after adjustment for potential confounders such as body composition indices and metabolic factors." ([https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8436563](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8436563))

**Is LDL cholesterol associated with long-term mortality among primary prevention adults? A retrospective cohort study from a large healthcare system (2024)**  
"Among primary prevention-type patients aged 50–89 years without diabetes and not on statin therapy, the lowest risk for long-term mortality appears to exist in the wide LDL-C range of 100–189 mg/dL, which is much higher than current recommendations." [https://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/14/3/e077949](https://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/14/3/e077949)

And perhaps the most graphic and striking result, from a Korean university study of 13 million subjects. If you want to see it all in one place, so to Figure 2 and see who has the least and the highest mortality risk across all ages. 

**Total cholesterol and all-cause mortality by sex and age: a prospective cohort study among 12.8 million adults**: “Total Cholesterol (TC) ranges associated with the lowest mortality were 210–249 mg/dL in each sex-age subgroup. TC levels <200 mg/dL may not necessarily be a sign of good health.”  
[https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-018-38461-y](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-018-38461-y)

I have great respect for my primary physician whom I have known and worked with as my medical director and my authority for advanced life support for many years. But like so many, I know he has little time to keep up with specialty journals. And medical dogma is deeply embedded in academic medicine and practice. He always offers statins, and I cordially refuse. I think he'd fall off his stool if I ever accepted.
